title: In the 14th century, Rulman Merswin bemoaned how women of his time wore flashy and indecent clothing. What would risqué dresses have looked like in medieval Alsace? - Quora

response.answer_text: Costume historians consider that it was the 14th century that saw the emergence of modern conceptions of fashion in clothing. Prior to this, most garments had straight seams. They were similar to today’s abayas or kaftans, and relied on draping and belting for sizing and fit.  Carolingian queens, 10th - 11th century.  Typical pattern of early medieval dress. Rich and poor differed in the type and quality of the cloth, the dyes (particularly the depth of colour) and the ornaments (the attached ribbon, lace, fur), but the basic shapes were the same. In the 14th century, curved seaming appeared:  Buttons and lacing also made their appearance:   Buttons and lacing. Outer clothing was often laced at the back. These, together, permitted a much closer fit in clothing, and reduced the reliance on the shoulders to support the weight of cloth. Hello, cleavage!  And ankles!  Embellishments went crazy, sleeves got long and pointy, and head-dresses went bananas:  People sewed bells to their clothing, pieced together strange mixtures of cloth, and began wearing tight-fitting hose: think court jester:  Just a dedicated follower of fashion (NB: this was also the era when male attire began showing off legs and bums, and from which the codpiece originated).  The authorities and even the Church inveighed against this extravagance, not just the fitted tailoring and flesh on display, but the showiness, ornamentation, and sheer silliness of it all. Just dressing in the morning went through five or six of the 7 Deadly Sins.

The sideless surcoat was considered scandalous. It had the nickname “Windows to Hell.” The deep armholes gave a view to the fitted underdress which clearly defined the breasts and waist. http://www.bayrose.org/AandS/handouts/Sideless_Surcoat_web.pdf Women (and men) clearly violated sumptuary laws all the time, which would’ve been considered vulgar and indecent. Another Look: Sumptuary Laws in Medieval Europe
